messageBody:
## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for May 23, 2018 - May 29, 2018
##
## Message Issue Date: 2018-05-30T17:53:19Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2018-05-23T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2018-05-29T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20180530-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period. There were no significant flares or CMEs.     

Geomagnetic activity was at below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=3 for the reporting period. 

STEREO A IMPACT/PLASTIC instruments detected the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream around 2018-05-23. Solar wind speed reached values of ~600 km/s from 2018-05-23 to 2018-05-26.

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 10^5 pfu for the entire reporting period. 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low this week.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed 

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2018-05-30T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2018-06-05T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming week. There are several active regions present on the solar disk that have some potential for flares or CMEs. Geomagnetic activity is expected to be moderate for the upcoming week due to the expected arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream around late 2018-05-31.

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score


NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center/Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC, http://swrc.gsfc.nasa.gov ) Disclaimer

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for May 16, 2018 - May 22, 2018
##
## Message Issue Date: 2018-05-23T16:41:21Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2018-05-16T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2018-05-22T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20180523-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period. There were no significant flares or CMEs.     

Geomagnetic activity was at below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=3 for the reporting period. The highest values of Kp=3 occurred during the synoptic periods of 2018-05-17T10:00Z-03:00Z and 2018-05-17T09:00Z-15:00Z. This slight increase of geomagnetic activity was associated with a small coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR/ACE at L1 around 2018-05-16.  Solar wind speed reached values of >450 km/s on 2018-05-18.  Another coronal hole high speed stream was detected by DSCOVR/ACE at L1 around 2018-04-22.  Currently, solar wind speed has reached values around >500 km/s.  

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt were elevated close to the threshold level of 10^5 pfu at the beginning of the reporting period on 2018-05-16.  This was a continuation of the radiation belt enhancement that started on 2018-05-06T17:10Z.  This elevation of the energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt detected by GOES 13 was associated with the coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR/ACE at L1 around 2018-05-05.  On 2018-05-17, the fluxes decreased and had remained to nominal levels for the rest of the reporting period.   

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low for this reporting period.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2018-05-23T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2018-05-29T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming week. There are some active regions present at the solar surface that can produce flare and CME activity. An active region seen on the STEREO A EUVI images has had some minor activity since 2018-05-22.  This active region is close to be rotating to the Earth's facing side.  Geomagnetic activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming week due to the high speed stream described above.  

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score


NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center/Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC, http://swrc.gsfc.nasa.gov ) Disclaimer

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for May 09, 2018 - May 15, 2018
##
## Message Issue Date: 2018-05-16T18:56:03Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2018-05-09T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2018-05-15T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20180516-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period. There were no significant flares or CMEs.     

Geomagnetic activity was at below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=4 for the reporting period. The highest values of Kp=4 occurred during the synoptic periods of 2018-05-09T18:00Z-24:00Z, 2018-05-11T03:00Z-09:00Z, 2018-05-11T18:00Z-24:00Z and 2018-05-12T03:00Z-06:00Z. This slight increase of geomagnetic activity may be associated with the lingering effects of a coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR/ACE at L1 around 2018-05-05.  Solar wind speed continued to reached values of 650-700 km/s on 2018-05-09 and slowly decreased to nominal levels on the following days.

STEREO A IMPACT/PLASTIC instruments detected the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream around 2018-05-13. Solar wind speed reached values of ~500 km/s on 2018-05-14.

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt were above the threshold level of 10^5 pfu starting on 2018-05-09 and has remained elevated for the rest of the reporting period. This is a continuation of the radiation belt enhancement that started on 2018-05-06T17:10Z. These significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt detected by GOES 13 were associated with the high speed stream described above (see notifications 20180510-AL-001, 20180512-AL-001, and 20180514-AL-001). 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low to moderate this week due to the elevated energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt described above.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed 

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2018-05-16T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2018-05-22T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming week. There are several active regions present at the solar surface that can produce flare and CME activity. Geomagnetic activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming week due to the expected arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream around 2018-05-17.

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Radiation Belt Enhancement
##
## Message Issue Date: 2018-05-16T18:51:31Z
## Message ID: 20180516-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

This is an update to the notifications with Activity ID 2018-05-06T17:10:00-RBE-001 (notifications 20180506-AL-003, 20180506-AL-004, 20180508-AL-001, 20180510-AL-001, 20180512-AL-001 and 20180514-AL-001).

Energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt continue to be significantly elevated. GOES 13 "greater than 0.8 MeV" integral electron flux first exceeded 10^5 pfu starting at 2018-05-06T17:10Z and has continued to be elevated or close to this threshold, currently at around 94,000 pfu.

The elevated energetic electron flux levels are caused by a high speed stream starting at 2018-05-05T09:27Z, which reached a speed of around 700 km/s. The current solar wind speed is around 320 km/s.


NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2018-05-06T17:10:00-RBE-001. 

## Notes: 



NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center/Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC, http://swrc.gsfc.nasa.gov ) Disclaimer

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for May 02, 2018 - May 08, 2018
##
## Message Issue Date: 2018-05-09T23:07:23Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2018-05-02T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2018-05-08T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20180509-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low to moderate levels during this reporting period.  There was 1 C-type CME (see details below).  Based on preliminary heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center/Space Weather Research Center, it was estimated that this CME (starting at 2018-05-03T17:24Z) may impact Spitzer (glancing blow) and STEREO A (glancing blow).  The flank of the CME was estimated to reach Spitzer at around 2018-05-06T12:00Z (plus minus 7 hours) (see notification 20180504-AL-001) .  The CME arrival was detected by STEREO A IMPACT/PLASTIC instruments around 2018-05-07T10:00Z.

Geomagnetic activity was at moderate levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=6 for the reporting period.  The highest value of Kp=6 occurred during the synoptic period of 2018-05-06T00:00Z to 2018-05-06T03:00Z (see notifications 20180506-AL-001 and 20180506-AL-002).  This moderate increase in geomagnetic activity was associated with a coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR/ACE at L1 around 2018-05-05.  Solar wind speed reached values of >700 km/s starting on 2018-05-06.  Due to this activity, strong compression of the magnetosphere was detected by simulations carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center/Space Weather Research Center. Simulations indicated that the magnetopause separating magnetospheric and solar wind plasma was close to the geosynchronous orbit starting at 2018-05-05T14:33Z (see notification 20180505-AL-001).  

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt crossed the threshold level of 10^5 pfu starting at 2018-05-06T17:10Z and has remained elevated for the rest of the reporting period.  These significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt detected by GOES 13 were associated with the high speed stream described above (see notifications 20180506-AL-003, 20180506-AL-004, and 20180508-AL-001). 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low to moderate this week due to the elevated energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt described above.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
2018-05-03T17:24Z     ~635            C              -155/1                 33                          STEREO A                          
 

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2018-05-09T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2018-05-15T23:59Z

The solar activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming week.  There are several active regions present at the solar surface that can produce flare and CME activity.  Geomagnetic activity is expected to stay elevated at the beginning of the reporting period due to the high speed stream described above.  Currently, the energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt are still elevated above the threshold of 10^5 pfu and the solar wind speed detected by DSCOVR/ACE at L1 is still ~600 km/s. 
 
## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Radiation Belt Enhancement
##
## Message Issue Date: 2018-05-08T16:16:40Z
## Message ID: 20180508-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

This is an update to the notification with ID 20180506-AL-004. Energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt continue to be significantly elevated, crossing again at 2018-05-08T15:55Z. GOES 13 "greater than 0.8 MeV" integral electron flux first exceeded 10^5 pfu starting at 2018-05-06T17:10Z.

The elevated energetic electron flux levels are caused by the high speed stream starting at 2018-05-05T09:27Z.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2018-05-06T17:10:00-RBE-001.

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Geomagnetic Storm
##
## Message Issue Date: 2018-05-06T12:20:41Z
## Message ID: 20180506-AL-002
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Ongoing space weather storm in the Earth's magnetosphere. Geomagnetic Kp index has reached level 6 (moderate) during the synoptic period 2018-05-06T00:00Z to 2018-05-06T03:00Z. 

The storm is caused by high speed stream starting at 2018-05-05T09:27Z.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO, polar and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's ring current and auroral regions can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2018-05-06T00:00:00-GST-001.

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Magnetopause Crossing
##
## Message Issue Date: 2018-05-05T16:18:07Z
## Message ID: 20180505-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Strong compression of the magnetosphere detected. Simulations carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center/Space Weather Research Center indicate that the magnetopause separating magnetospheric and solar wind plasma is close to the geosynchronous orbit starting at 2018-05-05T14:33Z.

The activity is associated with  Interplanetary Shock with ID 2018-05-05T09:27:00-IPS-001 and  high speed stream starting at 2018-05-05T09:27Z.

NASA spacecraft at the geosynchronous orbits may be exposed to solar wind plasma and magnetic field conditions.

Activity ID: 2018-05-05T14:33:00-MPC-001.

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - CME (Spitzer, STEREO A)
##
## Message Issue Date: 2018-05-04T12:54:25Z
## Message ID: 20180504-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

C-type CME detected by STEREO A. 

Start time of the event: 2018-05-03T17:24Z.

Estimated speed: ~650 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 32 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): -155/-4 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates.

Activity ID: 2018-05-03T17:24:00-CME-001

Based on preliminary heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center/Space Weather Research Center, it is estimated that the CME may impact Spitzer (glancing blow) and STEREO A (glancing blow).  The flank of the CME will reach Spitzer at 2018-05-06T12:00Z and STEREO A at 2018-05-06T12:00Z (plus minus 7 hours). 

Links to the movies of the modeled event (includes CME: 2018-05-03T17:24:00-CME-001):

## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period. There were no significant flares or CMEs. 

Geomagnetic activity was at below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=3 for the reporting period. 

STEREO A IMPACT/PLASTIC instruments detected the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream around 2018-04-27. Solar wind speed reached values of ~600 km/s on 2018-04-28.

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 10^5 pfu for the entire reporting period. 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low this week.

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2018-05-02T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2018-05-08T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to be low for the upcoming week. There are several small active regions currently visible at the solar surface that could produce some flare or CME activity.  Geomagnetic activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming week due to the expected arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream around 2018-05-06.

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score
